column1: == History ==

Clearfield was one of the last communities to be settled in the northern part of Davis County (1877). Hunters and Native American warriors knew this land before the first white man settled here. They referred to it as the land of wind and sand. It was the arrival of the railroad that first awakened the area in 1869 and stirred the sleeping Sand Ridge
column2: which it was once known as until the name was later changed to Clearfield.There was no water for those early families until wells could be successfully dug. The only water available at first had to be hauled in large barrels from Kays Creek in East Layton. But the great event that did more to transform the bleak Sand Ridge into a fertile garden spot was the coming of the Davis and Weber Counties Canal in 1884. This caused an immediate population boom in the area as people plowed up the sagebrush
column3: cactus
column4: and prickly pears
column5: and homes and farms began to appear throughout the area.

The new building later acquired the name Pioneer School. North Davis Junior High School was built and opened its doors in 1939. The building cost approximately $170

Construction began on Hill Field (Hill Air Force Base) in 1940 and the facility eventually stretched along the eastern border of Clearfield. The base has since provided many jobs for civilians and is one of Utah's major employers.

column1: === Neighborhoods ===

column2: most of which are more business or industrial related than residential. In the southwestern portion of the city is a large industrial business center called The Freeport Center
column3: and the Clearfield Job Corps. Having the Job Corps next to one of the largest industrial centers in Northern Utah allows for on the job training for many of the programs offered. The Freeport Center began life in the 1940s as the Clearfield Naval Supply Depot

column1: === Climate ===
The climate of Clearfield City is characterized as semi-arid
column2: with four distinct seasons. Both summer and winter are long
column3: with hot
column4: dry summers and cold
column5: snowy winters
column6: and with spring and fall serving as brief but comfortable transition periods. The city receives 20.75 inches (527 mm) of precipitation annually. Spring is the wettest season (May is the wettest month)
column7: while summer is very dry. Snow occurs on average from November to April
column8: producing a total average of 24 inches (61 cm) yearly.

column1: The primary source of precipitation in Clearfield City is massive Pacific storms that move in from the Pacific Ocean along the jet stream from approximately October through May. Particularly cold storms have brought measurable snow as early as September and as late as May. After the Pacific train of storms has shut off and the jet stream has retreated far to the north during summer
column2: the primary source of precipitation is afternoon thunderstorms generated by monsoon moisture moving up from the Gulf of California during mid-to-late summer. Although rainfall can be heavy
column3: these storms are usually scattered in coverage and rarely severe.

column1: Clearfield City features large variations in temperatures between seasons. The hottest month is July
column2: and the coldest is January. The average temperature over the year is 53 °F. The record high temperature is 108 °F (42 °C)
column3: which occurred in July 2002
column4: while the record low is −26 °F (−32 °C)
column5: which occurred in January 1937.

column1: During mid-winter
column2: strong areas of high pressure often situate themselves over the Great Basin
column3: leading to strong temperature inversions. This causes air stagnation and thick smog in the valley from several days to weeks at a time and can result in the worst air-pollution levels in the U.S.
column4: reducing air quality to unhealthy levels. Aside from occasional heavy snows in winter
column5: severe weather is very rare.

column1: == Government ==
Clearfield City has a "six-member council" form of government
column2: with a city manager by ordinance. In this form
column3: the powers of municipal government are vested in a council consisting of six members
column4: one of which is the mayor.

column1: The mayor is
column2: except in limited circumstances
column3: a nonvoting member of the council. The mayor votes only when there is a tie vote of the other council members present
column4: when the council is voting on whether to appoint or dismiss the city manager
column5: or on an ordinance that enlarges or restricts the mayor's powers
column7: or functions. The mayor is the chair of the council and presides at all council meetings. The mayor also exercises ceremonial functions for the municipality such as ribbon cuttings and municipal appearances. The mayor may not veto an ordinance
column9: or appropriation passed by the council.

column1: Other powers and duties of the mayor in a six-member council form of government can be taken from the mayor and given to either the council or city manager by the adoption of an ordinance by the council. In 1966
column2: such an ordinance was passed in Clearfield City
column3: giving the city manager such powers and duties.

column1: By ordinance
column2: therefore
column3: the city manager is the chief executive officer of Clearfield City. This means that the city manager oversees the city's day-to-day operations
column4: and all employees of the city report to the city manager. The city council appoints and hires the city manager and the city manager reports to the mayor and council.

column1: In the six-member council form of government
column2: the council is the legislative body and is therefore primarily responsible for setting policy and adopting a balanced budget. The council enacts laws
column3: appropriates funds
column4: and reviews municipal administration. The city council shall elect one of its members to act as mayor pro tempore during the temporary absence or disability of the mayor. During such absence or disability
column5: the mayor pro tempore shall possess the powers of mayor
column6: except that the mayor pro tempore shall continue to cast votes as a member of the city council. The election of a mayor pro tempore shall be entered in the minutes of the meeting.
